awd_titl_txt: ERI: Decision Models for Designing and Managing the Curb Spaces in Urban Mobility Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Engineering Research Initiation (ERI) award will focus on the management of the curb spaces in cities as part of the smart city initiative. Curb spaces have evolved very rapidly with the arrival of new mobility services and increased needs for goods delivery. Currently, curb spaces are not only used for parking but also used for the pick-up/drop-off zone of ridesharing services, bike-share or scooter parking racks, delivery zones for online shopping companies, etc. Motivated by the need for effective use of curbs, this research aims to maximize three core metrics: access (ensuring that vehicles can find a curb space), timeliness (the ability to secure access to curb space as soon as possible), and economic opportunity for all residents (the ability of the city to have earnings not only from the parking but also from the other uses of the curb space). More broadly, this research has the potential to result in reduced carbon dioxide emissions, less time spent in traffic, decreased traffic hazards, increased business satisfaction due to more on-time deliveries, and less congestion. This research will also actively engage female and minority graduate and undergraduate students and promote engineering education.

This project takes advantage of collaborating with the City of Grand Rapids in Michigan to acquire meaningful real-world data for validating the models and deriving solutions. It aims to create rigorous analytical approaches to promote a broader understanding of the vehicle dynamics in urban mobility and inform the operational design of curb spaces in the city. The specific tasks of this research include: (1) development of stochastic dynamic capacity allocation and pricing models for curb space management; (2) expanding the purview of capacity and demand to include all possible uses of curb space other than parking (e.g., pickup/drop-off, loading/ unloading); and (3) testing the operational and financial viability of new dynamic pricing models that consider all different curb uses with varying demands. This research will lead to advances in mobility systems modeling and solution approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This ERI project brought together faculty from Industrial and Manufacturing Systems Engineering and experts from the City of Grand Rapids to develop advanced operations engineering methodologies for managing urban curb spaces more effectively.  Addressing the growing need for tools to optimize curb space use, the project focused on innovative strategies as part of a broader smart city initiative. It targeted three critical metrics: access, ensuring vehicles can reliably find available curb space; timeliness, reducing delays in securing access; and economic opportunity, maximizing city revenue through diverse and equitable curb space uses. The research led to the development of advanced models for capacity allocation and dynamic pricing. These models are not only effective in addressing the challenges of urban curb space management but are also generalizable to mid-sized cities across the United States and internationally. By providing actionable strategies to enhance mobility, reduce congestion, and support sustainable urban development, the project represents a significant step forward in creating smarter, safer, and more efficient urban environments. 

Key Outcomes and Intellectual Merit

This project achieved several key outcomes that enhance both the academic understanding and practical management of urban curb spaces. One major accomplishment was the development of a capacity allocation model, which advanced the evaluation and management of competing curb space demands. By modeling vehicle flow, the research identified optimal strategies for dynamically allocating curb space to various uses, such as parking, goods loading and unloading, and ridesharing services. This systematic framework enables cities to improve traffic flow efficiency while addressing diverse curb space needs.

In addition, the project introduced a dynamic pricing model to balance demand with limited curb availability. By adjusting prices in real-time based on demand and usage patterns, this approach promotes equitable and organized curb space usage while maximizing city revenue. These actionable pricing strategies provide city planners with tools that can be implemented effectively and efficiently. The operational and financial viability of these models was validated through numerical experiments and practical scenarios. The findings highlight the potential to reduce urban congestion and improve traffic flow. By integrating curb space management with broader traffic flow analysis, the research offers a comprehensive framework to address the interconnected challenges of urban mobility.

These innovations establish new pathways for managing curb spaces—one of the most underutilized yet essential assets in urban environments—and provide cities with practical tools to create more efficient, and more sustainable urban systems.

Broader Impacts

This project has made meaningful contributions to urban mobility, benefiting cities, businesses, and residents while addressing environmental, social, and educational goals.

One of the most notable potential impacts of this research is the environmental benefit that could arise from improved curb space management policies. By reducing idling and congestion, these strategies have the potential to lower carbon emissions, thereby supporting the sustainability of urban transportation systems. Additionally, by addressing the diverse needs of curb space users—such as delivery services, businesses, and individual travelers—the project has encouraged a more inclusive and equitable approach to urban mobility. Collaboration with the city of Grand Rapids, Michigan, provided valuable real-world data to refine the models, which are generalizable to other mid-sized cities and adaptable to various urban contexts.

In addition to these practical contributions, the project has had a meaningful educational impact. It has provided undergraduate and graduate students with opportunities to engage in innovative research, with a particular emphasis on involving female and minority students. The tools and data created were integrated into courses, giving students practical, real-world experience. Moreover, the findings have been disseminated through conferences, publications, and collaborations with city planners, helping bring these solutions into practice and improving mobility systems for safer, more efficient cities.
